CHÂTEAU CAPITOUL NARBONNE This vineyard hotel is a delicious combination of the rustic and the 
luxurious, writes Steve Dineen
CHÂTEAU CAPITOUL NARBONNE; This vineyard hotel is a delicious 
combination of the rustic and the luxurious, writes Steve Dineen
City A.M.
July 4, 2022 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2022 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 17
Length: 740 words
Byline: Steve Dineen
Body
WHAT IS IT? Pulling up to Château Capitoul at night gives only the smallest hint towards what to expect. The pitch 
black countryside just outside of Narbonne on the Mediterranean coast gives way to a long, tree-lined approach, at 
the end of which rests an imposing, underlit neo-gothic Château, which wouldn't look out of place on a windswept 
Yorkshire moor. Come morning that countryside reveals itself to be endless, rolling vineyards, beautifully framed by 
my shuttered third storey window.
Château Capitoul is several things at once: there's the aforementioned Château, essentially a boutique hotel of its 
own, with eight rooms connected by a central staircase complete with chandeliers and original art.
There's also a 44-villa "hamlet", with rooms varying in size from "very comfortable indeed" to "absolutely bloody 
massive". Some come with their own plunge pools, every room is en suite, and they're all built to make the most of 
the views across the vineyards to the Pyrenees or down to the ocean, which is a 10 minute drive away.
Then there's the working vineyard, winery and wine shop, where a range of bottles are produced, aged and sold. 
Renowned hoteliers Karl O'Hanlon and Anita Forte are beyond the project, having already seen huge success with 
sister properties Château Les Carrasses and Château St-Pierre de Serjac, both of which are nearby.
HOW DO YOU GET THERE? Capitoul is a 40 minute drive from Béziers airport, a tiny, one terminal affair serviced 
by Ryanair, who practically give away tickets on this route (there are some listed for this week for £21 return). 
Toulouse- Blagnac airport isn't much further, and Capitoul can arrange a car from either. Alternatively, you can 
CHÂTEAU CAPITOUL NARBONNE This vineyard hotel is a delicious combination of the rustic and the 
luxurious, writes Steve Dineen
catch the TGV from Paris, which will take a little under five hours but is a beautiful and relaxing way to travel. You 
could link up from the Eurostar, or, as I did, spend some time in the capital before heading south. WHAT'S IT LIKE?
Château Capitoul is almost incongruously luxurious compared to the working vineyards that surround it. Everything 
from the huge, sunbaked terrace to the infinity pool to the ever-present hiss of cicadas draw your attention out 
towards the vines, and a walk through the wild-looking but carefully planned gardens - designed by James Basson, 
if you're into that kind of thing - to inspect the grapes yourself is a must.
Rooms in the villa are in keeping with the rustic surroundings - mine featured views across to the mountains and 
plush velvet furniture, all intercut by dramatic wooden beams. It also came with a free-standing bath, which is the 
ideal location to sample the local produce.
The villas are more modern - the epitome of neutral-hued sophistication. Built around facilities including a pétanque 
alley and tennis courts, it reminded me of something from JG Ballad's novel Super Cannes, only with fewer 
murders. The villas and the Château sandwich the modern reception area, which also houses the main restaurant.
WHAT ABOUT THE FOOD? After breakfast Asado becomes a Mediterranean grill; I had an excellent grilled 
cuttlefish one afternoon and an equally well prepared lamb chop the next. The French don't mess this stuff up.
But if you want something special, you'll want to try the fine dining restaurant Mediterraneo, where chef Valere 
Diochet creates a pan-Mediterranean tasting menu using whatever he can find locally. There are the usual 
spherifications and emulsifications but the result is surprisingly restrained, simple dishes made in inventive ways. It 
only opened a few months ago but this is a Michelin star in the waiting - and at (EURO)90 for seven courses (plus 
the rest), it's not unreasonable, either.
WHAT ELSE? You can arrange to hire a bike or jump in the car and drive to the beach but I opted to stay on-site, 
taking a tour of the vineyard and then tasting the produce myself. You can tailor a tasting to your tastes and wallet - 
I sampled the current range and finished with a splash of the 2003 La Clape, one of the most notable vintages of 
recent times. I recommend doing the tasting before dinner so you can order from the wine list with authority.
Elsewhere you can book a massage at the subterranean spa, wander the vineyards, or simply lie by the pool, 
listening to the cicadas and watching the grapes grow.
An overnight stay in a hotel room at Château Capitoul is from (EURO)220 on a B&B basis. For further information 
visit www.chateaucapitoul.com or call +33 (0) 448 22 07 24.
Load-Date: July 4, 2022
End of Document
Ryanair June Passenger Traffic Up 203% YoY
Ryanair June Passenger Traffic Up 203% YoY
RTT News (United States)
July 4, 2022 Monday
Copyright 2022 Content Engine, LLC.
All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2022 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 82 words
Byline: editorial@rttnews.com,  (RTT Staff Writer)
Body
       Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA.L, RYAAY) said it recorded passenger traffic of 15.9 million for the month of June, 
compared to traffic of 5.3 million, for the same month of prior year. Load Factor for the month was 95%, compared 
to 72%, a year ago, an increase of 23 percentage points. The company operated over 88,500 flights in June.
 For the rolling annual period, passenger traffic was 134.5 million, up 283% from prior year. Load factor was 86%, 
an increase of 14 percentage points.        
Load-Date: August 16, 2022
End of Document
Ryanair ( RYAAY ) Faces Strike Action by Cabin Crew in Spain
Ryanair (RYAAY) Faces Strike Action by Cabin Crew in Spain
Newstex Blogs 
Zacks Investment Research
July 4, 2022 Monday 4:45 PM EST
Copyright 2022 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1239 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Jul 04, 2022( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  
 Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[1] staff across various parts of Europe have been on strike lately as they demand 
improved pay and better working conditions. To this end, per a Reuters report[2], Ryanair's Spain-based cabin crew 
announced its plans to strike for 12 days this month. The dates are Jul 12-15, 18-21 and 25-28 across 10 Spanish 
airports. This latest announcement came on the final day of the crew's current strike, leading to the cancellation of 
10 flights in Spain on Jul 2. 
A Spain-based cabin crew at easyJet are striking for nine days this month for higher pay. easyJet canceled five 
flights from Spain on Jul 2. Paris' Charles de Gaulle airport workers were on strike on Jul 1 and Jul 2, leading to the 
cancellation of almost 10% of flights. 
Meanwhile, a popular holiday destination in Portugal (despite facing no ongoing strikes) is expected to suffer from 
65 flight cancellations to and from Lisbon on Jul 2, backed by a combined impact of flight disruptions at multiple 
European airports. 
So far, despite facing strikes in recent days by cabin crew unions in Belgium, Spain, Portugal, France and Italy, 
Ryanair claims to have witnessed minimal impact on its operations over the Jun 24-26 weekend. 
RYAAY continues to hope that impending strikes may not affect its operations. However, Air Traffic Control strikes 
and airport staff shortages across Europe are some factors that can cause minor travel chaos. 
Such flight disruptions due to staff shortage during the peak summer travel period seem to be a hindrance for this 
Zacks Rank #4 (Sell) European carrier. Notably, shares of RYAAY have lost 32.9% year to date compared with 
23.1% loss of the industry[3] it belongs to. 
Image Source: Zacks Investment Research 
The negativity surrounding the stock is evident from the Zacks Consensus Estimate for current-year earnings being 
revised 11.6% downward over the past 90 days. Stocks to Consider Some better-ranked stocks in the broader 
ZacksTransportation[4]sector are Kirby KEX[5], C.H. Robinson Worldwide CHRW[6] andDiana Shipping Inc. 
DSX[7], each carrying a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). You can see the complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) 
stocks here.[8] 
Kirby has an expected earnings growth rate of 278.57% for the current year. KEX delivered a trailing four-quarter 
earnings surprise of 7.7%, on average. 
Kirby has a long-term earnings growth rate of 12%. Shares of KEX have gained 2.3% so far this year.

C.H. Robinson has an expected earnings growth rate of 15.9% for the current year. CHRW delivered a trailing four-
quarter earnings surprise of 17.1%, on average. 
C.H. Robinson has a long-term earnings growth rate of 9%. Shares of CHRW have gained 8.8% over the past year. 
Diana has an expected earnings growth rate of 265.1% for the current year. The Zacks Consensus Estimate of 
Diana's current-year earnings has improved 5.4% over the past 90 days. 
Shares of DSX have gained 18% so far this year.

Inspire Investing LLC Takes Position in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY )
Inspire Investing LLC Takes Position in Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
July 3, 2022 Sunday
Copyright 2022 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 640 words
Body
Ryanair Inspire Investing LLC purchased a new stake in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get 
Rating ) in the first quarter, according to its most recent filing with the SEC. The firm purchased 12,486 shares of 
the transportation company's stock, valued at approximately $1,088,000.  
Several other hedge funds also recently bought and sold shares of the company. Fifth Third Bancorp increased its 
stake in shares of  Ryanair by 1,124.4% during the 4th quarter. Fifth Third Bancorp now owns 551 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $56,000 after purchasing an additional 506 shares in the last quarter.  
Mitsubishi UFJ Kokusai Asset Management Co. Ltd. increased its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 97.6% during the 
4th quarter. Mitsubishi UFJ Kokusai Asset Management Co. Ltd. now owns 1,083 shares of the transportation 
company's stock worth $115,000 after purchasing an additional 535 shares in the last quarter.  Point72 Europe 
London LLP purchased a new position in shares of  Ryanair during the 4th quarter worth approximately $201,000.  
Americana Partners LLC purchased a new position in shares of  Ryanair during the 4th quarter worth approximately 
$239,000.  Finally, Mercer Global Advisors Inc. ADV increased its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 16.1% during the 
4th quarter. Mercer Global Advisors Inc. ADV now owns 2,566 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$263,000 after purchasing an additional 356 shares in the last quarter.  
Shares of Ryanair stock  opened at $68.65 on Friday. The firm's 50-day simple moving average is $81.21 and its 
200-day simple moving average is $94.02. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.67, a quick ratio of 1.01 and 
a current ratio of 1.01. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1 year low of $65.31 and a 1 year high of $127.25.  
RYAAY has been the subject of several recent analyst reports. Berenberg Bank lowered their target price on shares 
of Ryanair from  20.00 ($21.28) to  19.50 ($20.74) and set a "buy" rating for the company in a research note on 
Friday, May 20th. Morgan Stanley lowered their target price on shares of Ryanair from  21.00 ($22.34) to  20.00 
($21.28) in a research note on Tuesday, March 29th. Raymond James raised shares of Ryanair from an 
"outperform" rating to a "strong-buy" rating and set a $125.00 price objective for the company in a research note on 
Tuesday, May 17th. JPMorgan Chase & Co. reduced their target price on shares of Ryanair from  21.00 ($22.34) to  
20.50 ($21.81) and set an "overweight" rating on the stock in a report on Tuesday, May 17th. Finally, UBS Group 
lifted their target price on shares of Ryanair from  18.90 ($20.11) to  19.20 ($20.43) in a report on Thursday, May 
19th. Three investment analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating, twelve have issued  a buy rating and one  
has given a strong buy rating to the company. According to MarketBeat, Ryanair  has a consensus rating of 
"Moderate Buy" and an average price target of $71.18. 
About Ryanair (Get Rating ) 
Inspire Investing LLC Takes Position in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY )
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing of car hire and accommodation services, and travel insurance through its website and 
mobile app.

supplies to cut demand to sustainable level; the move puts factory owners at a risk of energy rationing this 
winter.

lease sales in Alaska’s south coast and Gulf of Mexico.

perceptions of Threadneedle Street’s independence.

clients as the tech giant struggles to fulfil its promise to host the IT systems for Ukraine’s entire government 
on its remote servers.

Industries' CO2 factory in Ince, Cheshire, which could save hundreds of jobs.

the luxury marque tapped owners Geely of China, Malaysia’s Etika Automotive and Santander to raise the 
funds.

Ryanair CEO Sees Higher Fares In Five Years Amid Soaring Oil Costs, Environmental Fees
Ryanair CEO Sees Higher Fares In Five Years Amid Soaring Oil Costs, 
Environmental Fees
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
July 3, 2022 Sunday 11:57 PM EST
Copyright 2022 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 95 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYA.IR) Chief Executive Officer Michael O'Leary expects ticket prices to increase in the next five years to 
make a profit as airlines face higher oil prices and environmental charges, London's Financial Times reported on 
July 2.
Airlines in Europe and the US recently raised fares amid the summer travel boom, which also forced some air 
carriers to reduce capacity due to staff shortages. 
In the medium term, O'Leary estimates the average Ryanair fare to reach 50 euros to 60 euros ($52.15 to $62.58) 
from 40 euros.
Ryanair shares gained 2% at the close of July 1.
Load-Date: July 4, 2022
End of Document
Ryanair Still Expects Minimal Flight Disruptions as Spanish Crew Plans 12-day Strike
Ryanair Still Expects Minimal Flight Disruptions as Spanish Crew Plans 12-
day Strike
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
July 3, 2022 Sunday 11:49 PM EST
Copyright 2022 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 141 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYA.IR) continues to expect "minimal (if any) disruptions" to its flights in July despite a planned 12-day 
strike by its Spain-based crew, according to a Sunday statement from the Irish budget airline.
The carrier added that the Europe-wide air traffic control strikes and airport staff shortages may lead to minor 
disruptions and travelers will be notified via email or SMS.
The statement follows labor unions USO and SICTPLA's announcement that they will again go on strike from July 
12-15, 18-21, and 25-28, across 10 Spanish airports where Ryanair has operations. The organizations also urged 
the Spanish labor ministry to compel Ryanair in following the country's laws.
During an initial six-day strike in June, 215 flights to or from Spain were canceled, with over 1,255 delayed.
Ryanair traded 2% in the green at the close of July 1.
Load-Date: July 4, 2022
End of Document
More airline strikes to hit Spain , causing trouble for holiday season
More airline strikes to hit Spain, causing trouble for holiday season
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 2, 2022 Saturday 6:35 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 246 words
Dateline: Madrid (dpa) - 
Body
The cabin crew staff at low-cost airline Ryanair plans to strike for better working conditions on 12 more days in July, 
as a wave of industrial action hits Spain during the busy holiday season.
The walkouts have been scheduled for July 12-15, 18-21, and 25-28, the Spanish unions USO and Sitcpla 
announced on Saturday.
Numerous airports are affected by the Ryanair strikes: Madrid, Barcelona and Mallorca, as well as Málaga, Seville, 
Alicante, Valencia, Girona, Ibiza and Santiago de Compostela.
Ryanair cabin crew had already gone on strike in Spain at the end of June and also between Thursday and 
Saturday. The Irish airline "does not respect court rulings and laws and uses fear, coercion and threats against its 
workers," USO said. Labour Minister Yolanda Díaz must intervene, it said.
The cabin crew of rival airline Easyjet will also stop work in Spain on a total of nine days between through the end 
of July - as early as this weekend, as well as between July 15-17 and between July 29-31.
In the case of the British airline, the cabin crew is demanding significantly higher salaries as well as a limit to flying 
times, as is the case in other countries.
On Saturday, 15 flights were cancelled throughout Spain by the afternoon because of the strikes - 10 Ryanair and 
five Easyjet flights - state television station RTVE reported, citing the authorities. In addition, there were around 200 
delays.
However, there were no cancellations on Mallorca on Saturday for the time being.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
More airline strikes to hit Spain , causing trouble for holiday season
Load-Date: July 2, 2022
End of Document

"overweight" rating for the company in a research note on Tuesday, May 17th. StockNews.com  began coverage on 
Ryanair in a research note on Thursday, March 31st. They issued a "hold" rating for the company. Finally, 
Berenberg Bank reduced their price target on Ryanair from  20.00 ($21.28) to  19.50 ($20.74) and set a "buy" rating 
for the company in a research note on Friday, May 20th. Three equities research analysts have rated the stock with 
a hold rating, twelve have assigned  a buy rating and one  has assigned  a strong buy rating to the company. Based 
on data from MarketBeat, Ryanair presently has a consensus rating of "Moderate Buy" and a consensus price 
target of $71.18. 
The business has a 50-day moving average price of $81.21 and a two-hundred day moving average price of 
$94.06. The stock has a market capitalization of $15.58 billion, a P/E ratio of -54.48 and a beta of 1.37. The 
company has a current ratio of 1.01, a quick ratio of 1.01 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.67.

worth $115,000 after buying an additional 535 shares in the last quarter.  Migdal Insurance & Financial Holdings 
Ltd. raised its holdings in shares of  Ryanair by 55.7% during the 1st quarter. Migdal Insurance & Financial Holdings 
Ltd. now owns 1,183 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $100,000 after buying an additional 423 
shares in the last quarter.  Finally, Compagnie Lombard Odier SCmA acquired a new position in shares of  Ryanair 
during the 1st quarter worth $122,000.  
About Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY ) 
Ryanair ( NASDAQ : RYAAY ) Hits New 52-Week Low at $65.61
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing of car hire and accommodation services, and travel insurance through its website and

More airline strikes to hit Spain, causing trouble for holiday season
More airline strikes to hit Spain, causing trouble for holiday season
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 2, 2022 Saturday 9:14 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 318 words
Byline: Emilio Rappold in Madrid
Dateline: Madrid (dpa) - 
Body
The cabin crew staff at low-cost airline Ryanair plans to strike for better working conditions on 12 more days in July, 
as a wave of industrial action hits Spain during the busy holiday season.
The walkouts have been scheduled for July 12-15, 18-21, and 25-28, the Spanish unions USO and Sitcpla 
announced on Saturday.
Numerous airports are affected by the Ryanair strikes: Madrid, Barcelona and Mallorca, as well as Málaga, Seville, 
Alicante, Valencia, Girona, Ibiza and Santiago de Compostela.
Ryanair cabin crew had already gone on strike in Spain at the end of June and also between Thursday and 
Saturday. The Irish airline "does not respect court rulings and laws and uses fear, coercion and threats against its 
workers," USO said. Labour Minister Yolanda Díaz must intervene, it said.
The cabin crew of rival airline Easyjet will also stop work in Spain on a total of nine days between through the end 
of July - as early as this weekend, as well as between July 15-17 and between July 29-31.
In the case of the British airline, the cabin crew is demanding significantly higher salaries as well as a limit to flying 
times, as is the case in other countries.
On Saturday, 15 flights were cancelled throughout Spain by the afternoon because of the strikes - 10 Ryanair and 
five Easyjet flights - state television station RTVE reported, citing the authorities. In addition, there were around 200 
delays.
However, there were no cancellations on Mallorca on Saturday for the time being.
More airline strikes to hit Spain, causing trouble for holiday season
Because of the maintenance of "minimum services" prescribed by Spanish legislation in the event of strikes, only 
some flights, often only a relatively small proportion - may be cancelled.
In the case of the Ryanair strikes, for example, the Transport Ministry in Madrid decided that between 73% (Alicante 
and Palma de Mallorca) and 82% (Ibiza) of all programmed flights must be completed on the strike days, depending 
on the airport.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 2, 2022
End of Document
Air travellers face years of rising fares, warns Ryanair 's O'Leary Flying has become 'too cheap' ? Fuel and staff 
costs hit hard ? Anger over Brexit effect
Air travellers face years of rising fares, warns Ryanair's O'Leary; Flying has 
become 'too cheap' ? Fuel and staff costs hit hard ? Anger over Brexit effect
Financial Times (London, England)
July 2, 2022 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2022 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1
Length: 494 words
Byline: PHILIP GEORGIADIS
Body
Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary, pioneer of low-cost travel in Europe, has warned that fares will rise for the next five 
years because flying has become "too cheap" to make profits as industry costs spiral.
His comments came as ticket prices have risen in Europe and the US as passengers return and some airlines cut 
capacity because of staff shortages.
"It's got too cheap for what it is. I find it absurd every time that I fly to Stansted, the train journey into central London 
is more expensive than the air fare," he said in an interview with the Financial Times. A combination of high oil 
prices and environmental charges will push the average Ryanair fare up from (EURO)40 to between (EURO)50 and 
(EURO)60 over the medium term, he added.
O'Leary turned Ryanair into the biggest airline in Europe by ruthlessly cutting costs, and passing the savings on to 
consumers through cheap tickets.
"It has been my doing [making air travel cheap]. I made a lot of money doing it. But ultimately, I don't believe air 
travel is sustainable over the medium term at an average fare of (EURO)40. But I think, you know, it will still be very 
cheap and affordable at (EURO)50 and (EURO)60."
Air travellers face years of rising fares, warns Ryanair 's O'Leary Flying has become 'too cheap' ? Fuel and staff 
costs hit hard ? Anger over Brexit effect
Median fares from London to summer destinations in Portugal, Spain and Greece have all jumped compared with a 
year ago, although they are significantly lower than 10 years ago, according to data from www.Kayak.com.
Ryanair rivals EASYJET and Wizz Air have also reported higher fares in recent investor updates but O'Leary is one 
of the first airline bosses to warn about an increase in fares in the longer term.
The Ryanair boss expects oil prices to remain "structurally higher" for four or five years and wider inflationary 
pressures to hit the industry next year, including staff costs and air traffic control charges.
He also highlighted the impact of environmental charges, under which airlines buy tradeable credits to cover the 
amount they pollute under parallel emissions systems in the UK and the EU.
O'Leary fired a broadside at the government over Brexit for stopping airlines easily recruiting European workers, 
which the industry says has worsened staff issues. "This is without doubt one of the inevitable consequences of the 
disaster that has been Brexit," he said. "Withdrawing from the single market, just so that they can say 'we got Brexit 
done' was the height of idiocy."
Ryanair has been virtually the only major carrier in Europe to dodge the staff shortage disruption as it did not sack 
swaths of its staff when Covid-19 struck. But O'Leary refused to criticise other airlines for their decisions during the 
pandemic. "I would not be critical of competitor airlines. Covid has been unbelievably difficult to manage your way 
through."
The Department for Transport said there had been disruption around the world because of staff shortages. "It is not 
obvious that reaching for the lever marked 'more immigration' will solve the problem," it said.
Cruise liners juggle debt page 15
Graphic
 
Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary was critical of the impact of Brexit on staffing, saying withdrawal from the single 
market was the 'height of idiocy' Yves Herman/Reuters
Load-Date: July 1, 2022
End of Document
Ryanair chief warns fares will increase because flying is 'too cheap'; Airlines
Ryanair chief warns fares will increase because flying is 'too cheap'; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
July 2, 2022 Saturday
Edition 1, Asian Edition
Copyright 2022 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 12
Length: 473 words
Byline: PHILIP GEORGIADIS
Body
Michael O'Leary, the pioneer of lowcost travel in Europe, has warned fares will rise for the next five years because 
flying has become "too cheap" to make profits as industry costs spiral.
The Ryanair boss's warning comes as ticket prices have risen in Europe and the US this summer as passengers 
return and some airlines cut capacity because of staff shortages.
"It's got too cheap for what it is. I find it absurd every time that I fly to Stansted, the train journey into central London 
is more expensive than the air fare," he said in an interview with the Financial Times.
He said he expected a combination of high oil prices and environmental charges to push the average Ryanair fare 
up from (EURO)40 to between (EURO)50 and (EURO)60 over the medium term.
O'Leary fired a broadside at the British government for "the disaster" of Brexit that had stopped airlines easily 
recruiting European workers, which the industry says has worsened staff shortages this summer. "This is without 
doubt one of the inevitable consequences of the disaster that has been Brexit," he said. "Withdrawing from the 
single market, just so that they can say 'we got Brexit done' was the height of idiocy. But then they are idiots."
O'Leary turned Ryanair from a small regional carrier in the 1990s into the biggest airline in Europe by ruthlessly 
cutting costs and passing savings to consumers through cheap ticket prices.
Ryanair chief warns fares will increase because flying is 'too cheap'; Airlines
"It has been my doing [making air travel cheap]. I made a lot of money doing it. But, ultimately, I don't believe air 
travel is sustainable over the medium term at an average fare of (EURO)40. It's too cheap at that. But I think, you 
know, it will still be very cheap and affordable at (EURO)50 and (EURO)60."
Median fares from London to summer destinations in Portugal, Spain and Greece have all jumped compared with a 
year ago, although they are significantly lower than 10 years ago, according to data from www.Kayak.com.
O'Leary is one of the first airline bosses to warn about an increase in fares in the longer term. The airline had 
hedged the majority of its fuel requirements for the rest of this year at $65 a barrel before Russia invaded Ukraine, 
saving it from the worst impact of the sharp rise in prices.
But the Ryanair boss still thinks fares will rise as he expects oil prices to remain "structurally higher" for the next 
four or five years, "until we can wean ourselves off Russian oil and gas" and wider inflationary pressures to hit the 
airline industry next year, including staff costs and air traffic control charges.
The UK Department for Transport said there had been disruption around the world because of staff shortages. "It is 
not obvious that reaching for the lever marked 'more immigration' will solve the problem," it said.
'I don't believe air travel is sustainable over the medium term at an average fare of (EURO)40'
Load-Date: July 1, 2022
End of Document

ANTIPODES PARTNERS Ltd Sells 1,403,849 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY )
ANTIPODES PARTNERS Ltd Sells 1,403,849 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)
Newstex Blogs 
Transcript Daily
July 2, 2022 Saturday 2:11 PM EST
Copyright 2022 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1112 words
Body
Jul 02, 2022( Transcript Daily: https://transcriptdaily.com Delivered by Newstex)  
 ANTIPODES PARTNERS Ltd reduced its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1] - Get 
Rating[2]) by 97.8% in the first quarter, HoldingsChannel.com[3] reports. The fund owned 31,948 shares of the 
transportation company's stock after selling 1,403,849 shares during the quarter. ANTIPODES PARTNERS Ltd's 
holdings in Ryanair were worth $2,783,000 at the end of the most recent reporting period.  
Other large investors also recently made changes to their positions in the company. Diversified Trust Co raised its 
holdings in shares of Ryanair by 1.6% during the 4th quarter. Diversified Trust Co now owns 39,895 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $4,082,000 after buying an additional 618 shares in the last quarter. 
Russell Investments Group Ltd. lifted its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 9.4% in the 4th quarter. Russell 
Investments Group Ltd. now owns 259,186 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $26,503,000 after 
acquiring an additional 22,275 shares during the last quarter. Verdence Capital Advisors LLC raised its position in 
Ryanair by 6.9% in the 4th quarter. Verdence Capital Advisors LLC now owns 6,793 shares of the transportation 
company's stock worth $695,000 after purchasing an additional 437 shares during the period. 180 Wealth Advisors 
LLC grew its position in Ryanair by 4.6% during the 4th quarter. 180 Wealth Advisors LLC now owns 2,584 shares 
of the transportation company's stock worth $293,000 after acquiring an additional 113 shares during the last 
quarter. Finally, Adelphi Capital LLP boosted its stake in shares of Ryanair by 4.9% during the fourth quarter. 
Adelphi Capital LLP now owns 1,161,249 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $118,830,000 
after purchasing an additional 54,705 shares during the period.  
Shares of Ryanair stock[4] opened at $68.65 on Friday. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1 year low of $65.31 and a 1 
year high of $127.25. The firm has a market cap of $15.58 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of -54.48 and a beta of 
1.37. The company has a 50-day moving average of $81.21 and a 200 day moving average of $94.06. The 
company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.67, a current ratio of 1.01 and a quick ratio of 1.01.  
RYAAY has been the subject of a number of recent analyst reports. JPMorgan Chase & Co. lowered their price 
target on shares of Ryanair from €21.00 ($22.34) to €20.50 ($21.81) and set an "overweight" rating for the company 
in a report on Tuesday, May 17th. Sanford C. Bernstein upgraded shares of Ryanair from a "market perform" rating 
to an "outperform" rating and set a $107.00 target price for the company in a report on Tuesday, March 22nd. 
Berenberg Bank cut their target price on Ryanair from €20.00 ($21.28) to €19.50 ($20.74) and set a "buy" rating on 
the stock in a research note on Friday, May 20th. UBS Group upped their price target on Ryanair from €18.90 
ANTIPODES PARTNERS Ltd Sells 1,403,849 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY )
($20.11) to €19.20 ($20.43) in a research report on Thursday, May 19th. Finally, StockNews.com[2] assumed 
coverage on Ryanair in a research report on Thursday, March 31st. They issued a "hold" rating on the stock. Three 
investment analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating, twelve have assigned a buy rating and one has issued 
a strong buy rating to the company's stock. According to MarketBeat.com, Ryanair has a consensus rating of 
"Moderate Buy" and an average target price of $71.18. 
About Ryanair (Get Rating[2]) 
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing of car hire and accommodation services, and travel insurance through its website and 
mobile app.

European flights canceled and delayed amid ongoing strikes
European flights canceled and delayed amid ongoing strikes
Newstex Blogs 
Deutsche Welle World
July 2, 2022 Saturday 4:20 PM EST
Copyright 2022 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 715 words
Body
Jul 02, 2022( Deutsche Welle World: http://www.dw.de/top-stories/world/s-1429 Delivered by Newstex)  
 Airlines hoping to cash in on renewed demand are facing labor agitation after firing swathes of workers during the 
pandemic.Hundreds of flights from various European airports were canceled or delayed on Saturday as the industry 
struggles with ongoing worker strikes. 
Labor action by cabin crews at the two low-cost airlines EasyJet and Ryanair as well as by airport workers in 
Europe's second-busiest airport — Roissy-Charles de Gaulle in Paris — are causing major headaches for airlines 
just as the first school summer holidays begin after two years of pandemic restrictions. 
One in five flights from the main Paris airport were canceled on Saturday morning, while the EasyJet and Ryanair 
strike led to the cancellation of 15 flights to and from Spain with another 175 delayed. 
Ryanair's cabin crew also announced another 12 days of work stoppages. Paris airport workers said they will walk 
out again on July 8 to 10. 
Low-cast airlines facing further strike disruptions 
The striking cabin crews are demanding improvements to their working conditions and pay to put them in line with 
other European airlines. 
Ryanair employees have been striking since June 24, with the aim of bringing the company to the negotiation table, 
while EasyJet cabin crews joined the strike on Friday. 
"After six days of strike and in view of the unwillingness of the company to listen to its staff and its preference for 
leaving thousands of passengers grounded rather than sitting down to negotiate an agreement under Spanish law, 
we have been forced to call new strike days," Lidia Arasanz from the USO union that has organized the Ryanair 
workers was quoted by AFP as saying. 
Arasanz said that the initial strike had seen a total so far of "more than 200 flights canceled and almost 1,000 
delays," adding that the new strike could cause even more disruptions. 
Strike action in France and Scandinavia 
Airport workers at Roissy-Charles de Gaulle are fighting for a wage hike to balance out rising costs from inflation. 
They had been offered a 4% pay increase on the condition that they end the strike on Friday, but this was rejected. 
"A majority of workers think the offer is not good enough," Daniel Bertone, who represents the CGT union, was 
quoted by Reuters as saying. "They don't trust management and they don't accept the 'it's this or nothing' 
blackmail." 
The industry slashed thousands of jobs during the pandemic when people were unable or unwilling to fly, but they 
have been unable to refill positions as the new post-restrictions demand has soared. 
European flights canceled and delayed amid ongoing strikes
Airports in the UK and the Netherlands struggled to deal with the surge in traffic earlier in the year, while France 
was largely spared. 
Pilots for the Scandinavian SAS airline delayed a planned strike on Saturday after negotiations with company 
management showed some progress. If the 900 pilots go ahead with their strike, hundreds of flights per day will 
likely be canceled. 
ab/rs (dpa, AFP, AP, Reuters)

Body
Jul 02, 2022( Deutsche Welle Europe: http://www.dw.de/top-stories/europe/s-1433 Delivered by Newstex)  
 Airlines hoping to cash in on renewed demand are facing labor agitation after firing swathes of workers during the 
pandemic.Hundreds of flights from various European airports were cancelled or delayed on Saturday as the 
industry struggles with ongoing worker strikes. 
Labor action by cabin crews at the two low-cost airlines EasyJet and Ryanair as well as by airport workers in 
Europe's second-busiest airport — Roissy-Charles de Gaulle in Paris — are causing major headaches for airlines 
just as the first school summer holidays begin after two years of pandemic restrictions. 
One in five flights from the main Paris airport were cancelled on Saturday morning, while the EasyJet and Ryanair 
strike led to the cancellation of 15 flights to and from Spain with another 175 delayed. 
Ryanair's cabin crew also announced another 12 days of work stoppages. Paris airport workers said they will walk 
out again on July 8 to 10. 
Low-cast airlines facing further strike disruptions 
The striking cabin crews are demanding improvements to their working conditions and pay to put them in line with 
other European airlines. 
Ryanair employees have been striking since June 24, with the aim of bringing the company to the negotiation table, 
while EasyJet cabin crews joined the strike on Friday. 
"After six days of strike and in view of the unwillingness of the company to listen to its staff and its preference for 
leaving thousands of passengers grounded rather than sitting down to negotiate an agreement under Spanish law, 
we have been forced to call new strike days," said Lidia Arasanz from the USO union that has organized the 
Ryanair workers. 
Arasanz said that the initial strike had seen a total so far of "more than 200 flights cancelled and almost 1,000 
delays," adding that the new strike could cause even more disruptions. 
Strike action in France and Scandinavia 
Airport workers at Roissy-Charles de Gaulle are fighting for a wage hike to balance out rising costs from inflation. 
They had been offered a 4% pay increase on the condition that they end the strike on Friday, but this was rejected. 
"A majority of workers think the offer is not good enough," said Daniel Bertone, who represents the CGT union. 
"They don't trust management and they don't accept the 'it's this or nothing' blackmail." 
The industry slashed thousands of jobs during the pandemic when people were unable or unwilling to fly, but they 
have been unable to refill positions as the new post-restrictions demand has soared. 
European flights cancelled and delayed amid ongoing strikes
Airports in the UK and the Netherlands struggled to deal with the surge in traffic earlier in the year, while France 
was largely spared. 
Pilots for the Scandinavian SAS airline delayed a planned strike on Saturday after negotiations with company 
management showed some progress. If the 900 pilots go ahead with their strike, hundreds of flights per day will 
likely be cancelled.

Deutsche Welle Visit Germany
July 2, 2022 Saturday 3:25 PM EST

Body

Newstex)

pandemic.Hundreds of flights from various European airports were cancelled or delayed on Saturday as the

The striking cabin crews are demanding improvements to their working conditions and pay to put them in line with 
other European airlines. 
Ryanair employees have been striking since June 24, with the aim of bringing the company to the negotiation table, 
while EasyJet cabin crews joined the strike on Friday. 
"After six days of strike and in view of the unwillingness of the company to listen to its staff and its preference for 
leaving thousands of passengers grounded rather than sitting down to negotiate an agreement under Spanish law, 
we have been forced to call new strike days," said Lidia Arasanz from the USO union that has organized the 
Ryanair workers. 
Arasanz said that the initial strike had seen a total so far of "more than 200 flights cancelled and almost 1,000 
delays," adding that the new strike could cause even more disruptions. 
Strike action in France and Scandinavia 
Airport workers at Roissy-Charles de Gaulle are fighting for a wage hike to balance out rising costs from inflation. 
They had been offered a 4% pay increase on the condition that they end the strike on Friday, but this was rejected. 
"A majority of workers think the offer is not good enough," said Daniel Bertone, who represents the CGT union. 
"They don't trust management and they don't accept the 'it's this or nothing' blackmail." 
The industry slashed thousands of jobs during the pandemic when people were unable or unwilling to fly, but they 
have been unable to refill positions as the new post-restrictions demand has soared. 
European flights cancelled and delayed amid ongoing strikes
Airports in the UK and the Netherlands struggled to deal with the surge in traffic earlier in the year, while France 
was largely spared. 
Pilots for the Scandinavian SAS airline delayed a planned strike on Saturday after negotiations with company 
management showed some progress. If the 900 pilots go ahead with their strike, hundreds of flights per day will 
likely be cancelled. 
ab/rs (dpa, AFP, AP, Reuters)

European flights cancelled and delayed amid ongoing strikes
European flights cancelled and delayed amid ongoing strikes
Newstex Blogs 
Deutsche Welle Arts and Culture
July 2, 2022 Saturday 3:25 PM EST
Copyright 2022 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 711 words
Body
Jul 02, 2022( Deutsche Welle Arts and Culture: https://www.dw.com/en/tv/arts-and-culture/s-47176598 Delivered by 
Newstex)  
 Airlines hoping to cash in on renewed demand are facing labor agitation after firing swathes of workers during the 
pandemic.Hundreds of flights from various European airports were cancelled or delayed on Saturday as the 
industry struggles with ongoing worker strikes. 
Labor action by cabin crews at the two low-cost airlines EasyJet and Ryanair as well as by airport workers in 
Europe's second-busiest airport — Roissy-Charles de Gaulle in Paris — are causing major headaches for airlines 
just as the first school summer holidays begin after two years of pandemic restrictions. 
One in five flights from the main Paris airport were cancelled on Saturday morning, while the EasyJet and Ryanair 
strike led to the cancellation of 15 flights to and from Spain with another 175 delayed. 
Ryanair's cabin crew also announced another 12 days of work stoppages. Paris airport workers said they will walk 
out again on July 8 to 10. 
Low-cast airlines facing further strike disruptions 
The striking cabin crews are demanding improvements to their working conditions and pay to put them in line with 
other European airlines. 
Ryanair employees have been striking since June 24, with the aim of bringing the company to the negotiation table, 
while EasyJet cabin crews joined the strike on Friday. 
"After six days of strike and in view of the unwillingness of the company to listen to its staff and its preference for 
leaving thousands of passengers grounded rather than sitting down to negotiate an agreement under Spanish law, 
we have been forced to call new strike days," said Lidia Arasanz from the USO union that has organized the 
Ryanair workers. 
Arasanz said that the initial strike had seen a total so far of "more than 200 flights cancelled and almost 1,000 
delays," adding that the new strike could cause even more disruptions. 
Strike action in France and Scandinavia 
Airport workers at Roissy-Charles de Gaulle are fighting for a wage hike to balance out rising costs from inflation. 
They had been offered a 4% pay increase on the condition that they end the strike on Friday, but this was rejected. 
"A majority of workers think the offer is not good enough," said Daniel Bertone, who represents the CGT union. 
"They don't trust management and they don't accept the 'it's this or nothing' blackmail." 
The industry slashed thousands of jobs during the pandemic when people were unable or unwilling to fly, but they 
have been unable to refill positions as the new post-restrictions demand has soared. 
European flights cancelled and delayed amid ongoing strikes
Airports in the UK and the Netherlands struggled to deal with the surge in traffic earlier in the year, while France 
was largely spared. 
Pilots for the Scandinavian SAS airline delayed a planned strike on Saturday after negotiations with company 
management showed some progress. If the 900 pilots go ahead with their strike, hundreds of flights per day will 
likely be cancelled. 
ab/rs (dpa, AFP, AP, Reuters)

What are your rights when it comes to flight cancellations?
What are your rights when it comes to flight cancellations?
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
July 01, 2022
Copyright 2022 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News - Airlines; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 632 words
Body
Strikes, slowdowns and staff shortages are causing chaos with Europe's air travel, but what are your rights when it 
comes to flight cancellations?
Under EU rules, if your flight is cancelled the airline must give you a refund or reschedule the flight, even if it means 
using a different carrier.
You are also entitled to extra compensation and accommodation expenses, if necessary.
"If you have a storm or if you have a strike from the airport staff, for instance, which is an extraordinary 
circumstance, you don't have the right to compensation," Steven Berger, a legal officer at The European Consumer 
Organisation (BEUC), told Euronews.
"In other situations, you have the right to compensation. The amount of this compensation varies on the distance of 
your flights."
This can range from (EURO)250 to (EURO)600.
According to BEUC, airlines often leave passengers in the dark, failing to make the rules clear. It wants more 
regulations to include automatic compensation if things go wrong.
"There should be a deterrent effect on the airlines to avoid the replication of the different unfair practices or the fact 
that consumers have to wait for a month to be reimbursed. Where in the regulation it's seven days," Berger said.
"We need really to make sure that the rights are respected in terms of timeline for reimbursement. It should be in 
cash and not in vouchers. This should always be a decision of the consumers to be reimbursed in vouchers or not."
Belgian Daniel Rothier is one of the many victims of the recent spate of cancellations.
His trip to Verona earlier this month became a nightmare when his inbound flight was cancelled with no explanation.
"On June 7th we learnt, by email, that the flight on June 8th was cancelled," Rottier told Euronews. "The only 
solution proposed was to try to get a seat on the plane leaving on June 10th, two days later.
What are your rights when it comes to flight cancellations?
"We asked our Airbnb host if we could stay longer. After some trouble we managed to stay longer, although not at 
the same price...It was a Ryanair flight. They didn't give us any explanation. We tried to contact them by mail, 
telephone, but with no answer."
He is now claiming compensation for the extra costs incurred.
Ryanair disputes this claim, however.
It told Euronews in a statement that: "Ryanair is operating its full flight schedules this summer, with no disruptions 
due to staffing shortages, unlike many other airlines who have failed to plan adequately for the return of travel post 
COVID. Air Traffic Controller (ATC) strikes and airport staff shortages may cause minor disruption throughout the 
summer season.
"Any claims that Ryanair's compensation claim systems are unfair and complicated are completely false. All 
passengers who encounter disruption are informed of all their options and entitlements through email/SMS and all 
information is readily available on Ryanair.com."
In some cases, as in Brussels last week, flights were cancelled due to airport staff striking. In this case it is not the 
fault of the airline, raising even more questions about compensation.
Dublin airport has taken the matter into its own hands, announcing that it will refund passengers who have been 
affected by flight cancellations.
So far though, the Irish airport is an outlier, with many consumers still left out of pocket.
AirGuide and Pyramid Media connects you to an affluent, influential group of business and leisure travelers from 
across the globe with our Advertising Multimedia Network, Advertising eMail: advert@AirGuideOnline.com and

Load-Date: July 11, 2022
End of Document
Flights Cancelled In Spain Due To Ryanair , EasyJet Strikes
Flights Cancelled In Spain Due To Ryanair, EasyJet Strikes
Newstex Blogs 
International Business Times News
July 1, 2022 Friday 2:45 PM EST
Copyright 2022 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 458 words
Body
Jul 01, 2022( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)  
 Nine flights to and from Spain were cancelled on Friday and dozens of others delayed due to the latest strike by 
cabin crew at low-cost airlines Ryanair and EasyJet. 
The work stoppage over pay and working conditions comes as European schools are breaking up for the summer. 
The strikes add more headaches to passengers and the aviation sector, which has struggled with staff shortages as 
it struggles to recruit people after massive layoffs during the Covid pandemic. 
By 1:00 pm (1100 GMT) eight EasyJet flights had been cancelled and 21 delayed, the USO union which called the 
strike said. 
One Ryanair flight was cancelled and 113 were delayed, it added. 
 Striking Ryanair workers protest at Barcelona's El Prat airport Photo: AFP / Pau BARRENA  
EasyJet crew are set to strike during the first three weekends of July to demand parity in working conditions in line 
with other European airlines. 
The strike by Ryanair cabin crew in Spain, where there are some 1,900 employees, began on June 24 and is due to 
run until Saturday. It is affecting 10 of the airline's bases in Spain. 
On Thursday over 50 Ryanair flights to and from the country were cancelled because of the job action. 
A strike by the airline's crew between June 24 and 26 cancelled 129 flights. 
Flights from Paris' two largest airports, Charles de Gaulle and Orly, were disrupted on Friday for the second day in 
a row due to a strike by airport workers.

Ryanair extends A320 leases and eyes zero debt
Ryanair extends A320 leases and eyes zero debt
AirFinance Journal
July 2022
Copyright 2022 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 255 words
Byline: Alex Derber
Body
Ryanair has decided to extend by four years most leases of the Airbus A320 aircraft that operate for subsidiary 
Lauda.
Once finalised, the deal will lock in "material rent savings", said Ryanair.
The Dublin-based low-cost carrier said that extension, which runs until 2024, followed a review of Boeing 737NG 
leasing opportunities and "Boeing's failure to agree competitive pricing on a new aircraft order".   In May, Airfinance 
Journal reported that Ryanair had described a "phenomenal" response to an RFP to lease up to 50 used 
narrowbody aircraft.
The carrier exclusively operates Boeing 737 aircraft in its mainline operations, but inherited A320s when it acquired 
Laudamotion in 2019.
In September 2021, Ryanair end talks with Boeing over a potential 737 Max 10 order due to disagreements over 
pricing.
In the first quarter of its 2023 financial year, Ryanair reported revenues of (EURO)2.6 billion ($2.6 billion), seven 
times higher than in the previous year's quarter.
Net profit was (EURO)170 million for the three months to 30 June, versus a net loss of (EURO)273 million a year 
earlier.
Net debt at 30 June fell to (EURO)200 million from (EURO)1.45 billion at 31 March.
Despite peak capital expenditure this year and next, Ryanair expects to achieve to achieve a broadly zero net debt 
position over the next two years.
The airline is withholding guidance for fiscal year 2023 due to "limited visibility into the second half of second 
quarter and almost zero visibility into the second half, when we are typically loss making", it said.
Load-Date: August 15, 2022
Ryanair extends A320 leases and eyes zero debt
End of Document
Condor seeks narrowbody leases for earlier deliveries
Condor seeks narrowbody leases for earlier deliveries
AirFinance Journal
July 2022
Copyright 2022 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 270 words
Byline: Laura Mueller
Body
German leisure carrier Condor Airlines is tipped to place an order for Airbus A321s at the Farnborough air show but 
is in talks with lessors about earlier delivery slots, sources indicate.
The carrier is looking to secure positions ahead of the 2027 delivery date quoted by Airbus.
As part of its narrowbody fleet campaign, Condor also considered the Boeing 737 Max 10, sources add.
Airfinance Journal's Fleet Tracker shows that Condor operates a mostly leased fleet including 12 A320s, 10 A321s, 
four A330-200s, as well as 13 Boeing 757-300s and 13 767-300ERs.
In July 2021 Condor announced an order for 16 Airbus A330-900s to replace its 767 fleet. The order makes it the 
first German operator of the model. The first aircraft is expected to arrive in autumn 2022, while the replacement of 
the entire long-haul fleet is scheduled to be completed in mid-2024.
Condor's fleet campaign follows the EU's General Court ruling that upheld the legitimacy of government aid, 
following the collapse of its parent company Thomas Cook.
Ryanair challenged the $580 million German state-guaranteed loan for Condor, which had filed for insolvency in 
September 2019. On 18 May, the EU's General Court ruled Ryanair had failed to demonstrate any grounds for 
doubt regarding the European Commission's handling of the loan application.
"The General Court dismisses the action in its entirety.
"The applicant did not succeed in rebutting the Commission's findings that Condor's difficulties were the result 
mainly of the Thomas Cook group being placed into liquidation and not of an arbitrary allocation of costs within the 
group," the court said.
Load-Date: July 25, 2022
End of Document
Ryanair (LON:RYA) Shares Cross Below 50-Day Moving Average of $14.41
Ryanair (LON:RYA) Shares Cross Below 50-Day Moving Average of $14.41
Newstex Blogs 
Transcript Daily
July 1, 2022 Friday 2:11 AM EST
Copyright 2022 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 576 words
Body
Jul 01, 2022( Transcript Daily: https://transcriptdaily.com Delivered by Newstex)  
 Ryanair Holdings plc (LON:RYA[1] - Get Rating[2]) shares passed below its fifty day moving average during trading 
on Tuesday . The stock has a fifty day moving average of GBX 14.41 ($0.18) and traded as low as GBX 13.80 
($0.17). Ryanair shares last traded at GBX 14.42 ($0.18), with a volume of 1,030,829 shares trading hands.  
The stock has a 50-day simple moving average of GBX 14.41 and a 200 day simple moving average of GBX 14.82. 
The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 116.44, a quick ratio of 1.14 and a current ratio of 1.34. The stock has a 
market capitalization of 163.33 million and a P/E ratio of -24.94.  
Ryanair Company Profile (LON:RYA[1]) 
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and Other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, 
food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation and hotel services, car hire, and travel insurance through its 
Website and mobile app.

Ryanair Cancels 54 Flights In Spain As Crew Strike Enters Fourth Day
Ryanair Cancels 54 Flights In Spain As Crew Strike Enters Fourth Day
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
July 1, 2022 Friday 00:20
Copyright 2022 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 105 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYA.IR) on Thursday canceled 54 flights to and from Spain, while at least 300 were delayed due to the 
ongoing strike of crew members, the labor union USO said in a statement. 
The budget airline claimed that 100% of scheduled flights were operational, however, USO said it did not call for its 
full crew at certain airports. The labor organization also slammed Ryanair for bringing in crews from other countries 
to operate Spanish flights, an action that violates the right to strike.
The strike action, which entered its fourth day on Thursday, will continue until Saturday.
Ryanair declined nearly 3% on Thursday's close.
Load-Date: July 1, 2022

Deucalion extends A320 leases
Deucalion extends A320 leases
AirFinance Journal
July 2022
Copyright 2022 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 138 words
Body
Deucalion Aviation has extended the leases of three CFM powered Airbus A320 aircraft with Ryanair's subsidiary, 
Lauda Europe.
All three aircraft are part of the KDAC 2017-1 ABS portfolio for which Deucalion Aviation is the servicer. The aircraft 
are 2007-vintage A320s, Airfinance Journal's Fleet Tracker shows.
"We are pleased to have promptly concluded the lease extensions negotiations with Ryanair, a key strategic partner 
to Deucalion Aviation, which will see the Airbus A320ceo aircraft in operation within the Ryanair group for the 
foreseeable future," commented co-chief executive officer and chief operating officer Jon Skirrow.
Earlier this month Deucalion Aviation placed three 737-800 aircraft with Sun Express Airlines. Fleet Tracker shows 
that the 2011/12-vintage aircraft were previously operated by Pegasus Airlines.

BBAM grows lessee ledger
BBAM grows lessee ledger
AirFinance Journal
July 2022
Copyright 2022 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 128 words
Byline: Dominic Lalk
Body
BBAM's Incline Aviation has delivered a Boeing 737-800 freighter aircraft to new Tbilisi-based cargo carrier Camex 
Airlines.
The new entrant is led by chief executive George Seturidze.
Incline acquired the 2003-vintage 737 from Ryanair in 2021 and had it converted for freighter use, Airfinance 
Journal Fleet Tracker data shows.
Earlier this year BBAM closed its latest flagship aircraft leasing fund, Incline Aviation II, with total capital 
commitments of approximately $1.5 billion.
In 2017, the firm closed Incline Aviation I, an $881 million fund dedicated to investing in leased commercial aircraft.
BBAM has signed agreements for more than 30 conversions for 737-800 aircraft.
San Francisco-based BBAM has more than 500 aircraft and $18 billion of assets under management.
Load-Date: July 25, 2022
End of Document
SMBC AC wins used 737-800 mandate
SMBC AC wins used 737-800 mandate
AirFinance Journal
July 2022
Copyright 2022 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 159 words
Byline: Dominic Lalk
Body
Japanese bank-backed aircraft leasing company SMBC Aviation Capital (SMBC AC) has agreed a lease mandate 
with IAG carrier Air Europa covering three Boeing 737-800 aircraft, sources close to the deal say.
The deal comprises a 2012-vintage 737-800 and two 2009-manufactured 737-800s. The CFM56-equipped 
narrowbodies were previously operated by Ukraine Airlines International and Ryanair.
Earlier this year Madrid-based Air Europa said that it hoped to offer more capacity this summer than it did pre-
Covid.
The airline is also sourcing additional 737-800s from lessors including Stratos; it also is adding 787 widebody 
capacity by means of 18-month subleases from Norse Atlantic Airways.
SMBC AC has an owned, managed and committed fleet of over 730 aircraft. Established in 2001, the lessor was 
acquired in 2012 by a consortium comprising SMFG and Sumitomo.
In addition to the incoming 737-800s, Air Europa continues to lease five 787-8 widebodies from SMBC AC.

Deucalion arranges A320 sale
AirFinance Journal
July 2022
Copyright 2022 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 137 words
Byline: Olivier bonnassies

Deucalion Aviation has completed the sale of an Airbus A320 aircraft to ST Engineering's aviation asset 
management business.
The transaction was arranged on behalf of the aircraft owners. 
Jon Skirrow, co-chief executive officer and chief operating officer, said: "We are very pleased to have concluded 
this sale. Deucalion enjoys a very strong relationship with ST Engineering and this particular sale underlines our 
strategy to expand our business reach further with all of our clients. We wish ST Engineering every success and 
hope this first transaction together is one of many in the future".
Earlier this week Deucalion Aviation extended the leases of three 2007-vintage A320s with Ryanair's subsidiary, 
Lauda Europe.
All three aircraft are part of the KDAC 2017-1 ABS portfolio for which Deucalion Aviation is the servicer.

Ryanair agrees to restore pilots' pre-Covid pay
Ryanair agrees to restore pilots' pre-Covid pay
City A.M.
July 1, 2022 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2022 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 7
Length: 193 words
Byline: ILARIA GRASSO MACOLA
Body
RYANAIR and UK pilot union Balpa yesterday reached an agreement to restore pilots' pre-pandemic pay, after staff 
agreed a 20 per cent cut during the peak of the Covid-19 pandemic.
The airline pledged to increase its UK pilots' pay, as it forecasted its capacity will grow 115 per cent on pre-
pandemic levels this year.
Under the newly agreed deal,
Ryanair will restore 10 per cent now, and another 10 per cent next April, subject to the recovery of the business. 
Ryanair's pilots are also set to receive additional benefits, such as pay enhancements, until 2026.
"While the recovery from the impact of the pandemic is still ongoing and our industry faces significant challenges, 
this longterm agreement delivers stability, accelerated pay restoration, future pay increases and other benefit 
improvements for our UK pilots," said Ryanair's people director Darrell Hughes.
Hughes added the airline had renegotiated agreements with 70 per cent of its total pilots.
The news comes as Ryanair's EU staff joined a continent-wide wave of discontent and voted in favour of strikes. 
Last weekend, cabin crew members in Belgium, Portugal and Spain staged a three-day walkout.
Load-Date: July 1, 2022
Ryanair agrees to restore pilots' pre-Covid pay
End of Document
Ryanair welcomes UK union approval of post-COVID pay deal
Ryanair welcomes UK union approval of post-COVID pay deal
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
June 30, 2022
Copyright 2022 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News - Airlines; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 324 words
Body
Ryanair's UK pilots have approved a deal on restoring pay to pre-pandemic levels, the low-cost carrier has 
announced.
The Irish airline said that the deal, which was negotiated with UK pilots' union BALPA, covers the restoration of pay 
and will also deliver pay increases in the period to 2026.
"While the recovery from the impact of the pandemic is still ongoing and our industry faces significant challenges, 
this long-term agreement delivers stability, accelerated pay restoration, future pay increases and other benefit 
improvements for our UK pilots," People Director Darrell Hughes, said in a statement on June 30, 2022.
Ryanair has sprung back faster than other European carriers from the pandemic and expects to operate 115% of 
pre-COVID capacity this year. It said it is prioritizing restoring pay for its staff to "keep jobs secure and have a 
foundation for growth".
During the pandemic, Ryanair chose to keep staff on but at lower pay levels. Hughes said the airline was working 
with pilots and unions across Europe on new deals to restore pay.
"While 100% of our pilots across our European network are covered by 2020 Emergency Agreements, we continue 
to work with our pilots and their unions on new deals, similar to this one concluded with BALPA, and have 
successfully re-negotiated improved long-term agreements with 70% of our pilots, running until 2026 or 2027 as we 
prioritise pay restoration," Hughes concluded.

Some 50 Spain flights cancelled as Ryanair staff strike
Some 50 Spain flights cancelled as Ryanair staff strike
Alliance News UK
June 30, 2022 Thursday 8:21 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 309 words
Body
(Alliance News) - More than 50 Ryanair Holdings PLC flights to and from Spain were cancelled on Thursday and 
several hundred others delayed during a strike by the low-cost airline's cabin staff. 
The strike which took place as European schools were breaking up for the summer was the latest stoppage by 
European airline staff demanding better conditions. 
By 8:00 pm, 54 flights had been cancelled and more than 300 delayed, with the airports in Barcelona and Malaga 
worst-hit, the USO union said. 
Although Ryanair had said all scheduled flights would be operating, the airline "had not called in the full crew" at 
certain airports.
"The crew members that were not called in have joined the strike while those that were, went to the airports.. but 
there were not enough of them to operate the flights," it said. 
The strike by Ryanair cabin crew in Spain, where there are some 1,900 employees, is affecting 10 of the airline 
bases in the country and is due to run until July 2.
Earlier, the airline said flight disruption through the strike was "minimal" and only affected three percent of its 
Spanish flights.
The employees, who are demanding better working conditions, began an initial three-day strike on June 24 during 
which 129 Spanish flights were cancelled, the union said. 
Ryanair is the airline that transports the most passengers in the Spanish market, offering more than 650 routes to 
27 airports, the company says. 
The initial strike in Spain coincided with industrial action by the airline's staff in Portugal, Belgium, Italy and France 
demanding respect for labour rights and higher wages. 
Some 50 Spain flights cancelled as Ryanair staff strike
On Friday, staff with rival low-cost airline EasyJet will also be striking for the first of three weekends in July 
demanding parity in working conditions in line with other European airlines. 
source: AFP
Copyright 2022 Alliance News Limited. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: June 30, 2022

Which? calls for overhaul of travel rules
Which? calls for overhaul of travel rules
City A.M.
June 30, 2022 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2022 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 7
Length: 196 words
Byline: ILARIA GRASSO MACOLA
Body
CONSUMER champion Which? has called for a significant overhaul of travel rules to hold airlines accountable 
when they flaunt consumer laws.
The call comes at a delicate time for the aviation industry, which has been plagued for the last few weeks by a raft 
of cancellations and delays.
Which? today called on the government to expand the powers given to the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), so that it 
could hit airlines that break the law with hefty fines.
The group also suggested setting an airline code of conduct as well as making it mandatory for carriers to sign up to 
alternative dispute resolution schemes (ADR).
Under the current legislation, airlines and airports are not obliged to sign up to the ADR system, forcing travellers to 
go through lengthy court proceedings if they want to enforce their rights.
The appeal is based on an investigation by the consumer group, in which several airlines - including Ryanair, BA 
and TUI - were accused of breaking the law.
Carriers rebutted condemning Which?'s "unfounded and unsupported" allegations.
Commenting on the news, aviation analyst Sally Gethin said the government and CAA were already working on 
consumer protection measures.
Which? calls for overhaul of travel rules
Load-Date: June 30, 2022
End of Document

Ryanair celebrates 35 years at Birmingham and announces its winter schedule '22/23
Ryanair celebrates 35 years at Birmingham and announces its winter 
schedule '22/23
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
June 29, 2022
Copyright 2022 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News - Airlines; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 722 words
Body
Ryanair has announced its biggest ever Birmingham winter schedule, with an additional based aircraft for 
winter'22/23 and 5 new routes to exciting destinations such as Billund, Grenoble, Santander, Stockholm, and 
Toulouse to recognise 35 years at Birmingham Airport.
Ryanair's Birmingham based fleet will increase to 5 based aircraft, 2 of which will be new Boeing 737 8-200 
"Gamechanger" aircraft which deliver 4% more seats, burn 16% less fuel, and create 40% less noise emissions.
Ryanair's investment of over USD$500m at Birmingham will support 150 highly paid aviation jobs and over 1,850 
indirect jobs in the local area.
Ryanair's Birmingham winter'22 schedule will deliver:
5 based aircraft - 2 of which will be Boeing 737 8-200 "Gamechanger" aircraft
USD$500m investment in Birmingham
34 routes in total - 5 new: Billund, Grenoble, Santander, Stockholm, and Toulouse
Over 280 flights per week
Over 2,000 total jobs
Ryanair are operating a full schedule this summer across the UK and continues to invest and grow its network into 
winter '22, unlike other airlines who cannot operate their promised schedules efficiently and continue to disappoint 
UK holidaymakers.
Ryanair is leading the post-pandemic recovery across Europe with the help of traffic recovery schemes and lower 
airport charges. If the UK is to continue its recovery, the government needs to immediately support airlines by 
scrapping the aviation tax (APD) now in full, a 50% cut on domestic flights from April'23 is simply insufficient.
With 34 routes to choose from this winter, Birmingham customers and visitors can already book a well-deserved 
winter getaway, flying on the lowest fares to exciting new destinations such Billund, Grenoble, Santander, 
Ryanair celebrates 35 years at Birmingham and announces its winter schedule '22/23
Stockholm, and Toulouse. To celebrate its 35th birthday at Birmingham and an additional based aircraft, Ryanair 
has launched a seat sale with fares available from just £19.99 which must be booked by Friday, 1st of July for travel 
from October'22 - March'23, only on the Ryanair.com website.
From Birmingham, Ryanair Director of Route Development, Ray Kelliher said:
"Ryanair is delighted to announce further growth and investment at our Birmingham base this winter, with our 5th 
based aircraft, 5 exciting new routes and 2 brand new environmentally efficient Boeing 8-200 "Gamechanger" 
aircraft as we celebrate 35 years of successful operations at Birmingham Airport. Our now biggest ever Birmingham 
base will deliver 34 routes for Winter'22, including 5 new routes to destinations such as Billund, Grenoble, 
Santander, Stockholm, and Toulouse.
Lower aviation taxes and competitive airport charges provide the foundation for which Ryanair can deliver long-term 
traffic growth and increased connectivity. At a time when other airlines across the UK are cancelling flights and 
reducing their schedules, we're delighted to make this $100m further investment in Birmingham largely thanks to 
the hard work and support of the Airport. If the UK Government wants to see more investments from Ryanair and 
other airlines next Summer, they must scrap the APD tax for all flights, or otherwise put the UK (an island-based 
economy) at risk of losing air traffic to competing European countries.
To celebrate today's announcement and our 35th birthday at Birmingham, we are launching a seat sale with fares 
available from £19.99 for travel from October'22 until March'23, which must be booked by Friday, 1st July. Since 
these amazing low fares will be snapped up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and book early to 
avoid missing out."
Birmingham Airport Chief Executive, Nick Barton said:
"We are thrilled Ryanair is adding to its BHX-based fleet of aircraft as we toast 35 years of its operation here. This 
long-term move will give customers greater choice and boost economic growth in our region."

Manning & Napier Group LLC Sells 23,662 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY )
Manning & Napier Group LLC Sells 23,662 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
June 29, 2022 Wednesday
Copyright 2022 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 725 words
Body
Ryanair Manning & Napier Group LLC decreased its stake in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY  - 
Get Rating ) by 2.9% during the 1st quarter, according to the company in its most recent filing with the SEC. The 
firm owned 805,924 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 23,662 shares during the quarter. 
Manning & Napier Group LLC owned 0.36% of Ryanair worth $70,211,000 as of its most recent filing with the SEC.  
Several other large investors also recently bought and sold shares of RYAAY. Massachusetts Financial Services 
Co. MA increased its stake in  Ryanair by 6.4% in the fourth quarter. Massachusetts Financial Services Co. MA now 
owns 8,465,309 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $866,255,000 after acquiring an additional 
510,683 shares during the period.  Lazard Asset Management LLC increased its stake in  Ryanair by 5.8% in the 
fourth quarter. Lazard Asset Management LLC now owns 5,175,799 shares of the transportation company's stock 
valued at $529,638,000 after acquiring an additional 285,162 shares during the period.  William Blair Investment 
Management LLC increased its stake in  Ryanair by 7.1% in the fourth quarter. William Blair Investment 
Management LLC now owns 2,585,739 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $264,595,000 after 
acquiring an additional 172,064 shares during the period.  Lansdowne Partners UK LLP increased its stake in  
Ryanair by 11.5% in the fourth quarter. Lansdowne Partners UK LLP now owns 1,035,509 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $105,964,000 after acquiring an additional 106,451 shares during the 
period.  Finally, Gluskin Sheff & Assoc Inc. bought a new stake in  Ryanair in the fourth quarter valued at about 
$9,246,000.  
RYAAY  opened at $70.75 on Wednesday. The firm's fifty day moving average is $82.68 and its two-hundred day 
moving average is $94.65. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.67, a quick ratio of 1.01 and a current ratio 
of 1.01. The firm has a market cap of $16.05 billion, a PE ratio of -56.15 and a beta of 1.37. Ryanair Holdings plc 
has a twelve month low of $65.64 and a twelve month high of $127.25.  
Several analysts have weighed in on RYAAY shares. StockNews.com  started coverage on shares of Ryanair in a 
research note on Thursday, March 31st. They set a "hold" rating on the stock. UBS Group upped their price 
objective on shares of Ryanair from  18.90 ($20.11) to  19.20 ($20.43) in a research note on Thursday, May 19th. 
JPMorgan Chase & Co. decreased their price objective on shares of Ryanair from  21.00 ($22.34) to  20.50 
($21.81) and set an "overweight" rating on the stock in a research note on Tuesday, May 17th. Raymond James 
upgraded shares of Ryanair from an "outperform" rating to a "strong-buy" rating and set a $125.00 target price on 
the stock in a research report on Tuesday, May 17th. Finally, Morgan Stanley reduced their target price on shares 
of Ryanair from  21.00 ($22.34) to  20.00 ($21.28) in a research report on Tuesday, March 29th. Three research 
analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating, twelve have given a buy rating and one  has issued  a strong buy 
Manning & Napier Group LLC Sells 23,662 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ : RYAAY )
rating to the company. According to MarketBeat, the company presently has an average rating of "Moderate Buy" 
and an average target price of $71.18. 
Ryanair Company Profile (Get Rating ) 
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Germany, and other European countries. It is also involved in the provision of various 
ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing of car hire and accommodation services, and travel insurance through its website and 
mobile app.
